stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on Course 14, focusing on designing and implementing a pull-tab mechanism for a large cardboard box that opens into a 'hell' area. He troubleshooted the pull-tab's animation and debugged two major issues: a level-wide performance problem caused by an infinite draw distance setting, and a complex, emulator-specific bug that caused Mario to let go of Bowser.

development_findings.summary: Kaze replaced an initial 'zipper' idea for opening a box with a perforated pull-tab to better fit the game's crafty, cardboard aesthetic, showing a commitment to thematic consistency over novel technology.
development_findings.quote: a zipper feels so unfitting. Maybe if I Google cardboard box, there's some inspiration here.

development_findings.summary: A significant performance issue in Course 14 was traced back to an infinite draw distance setting accidentally carried over from a previous project, highlighting how legacy settings can impact development.
development_findings.quote: The reason it ran poorly is because back from my other RomHack, I still had the drawing distance for everything set at infinite.

development_findings.summary: Kaze fixed a complex, emulator-specific bug where Mario would drop Bowser by debugging the original SM64 code and discovering a vanilla function improperly used the 'action arg' and 'action state' variables interchangeably.
development_findings.quote: I now see why. Oh, does this have something to do with... that's so weird how that's done. This should work by action state not action arg.

development_findings.summary: The game will feature a bonus mission system called 'Yoshi Stars', inspired by Super Mario Galaxy's comets. Players will find a Yoshi who issues a special challenge (e.g., 'get the red coins with two or less A presses') to earn a star. Kaze plans for 45 such missions.
development_findings.quote: we've done Yoshi's Island has that but with Yoshi stars instead. So instead of a comet appearing there's going to be a Yoshi that gives you a mission where it's like do this with these special conditions and you get a star.

development_findings.summary: The game uses an updated Mario model with higher-resolution textures, 3D buttons, a colored line on his shoes, and new subtle animations like a jiggling nose.
development_findings.quote: The Mario model I have right now is like an HD-ified version of the normal Mario model... He also has new features like his nose jiggles.

context_findings.summary: Kaze does not track time spent on specific levels, preferring to focus entirely on the creative act of making the game.
context_findings.quote: I don't keep track of that. I just make games. I don't have space in my brain to think about those things.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that finishing a mod is a rare accomplishment and that his track record of completing projects is an exception in the modding community.
context_findings.quote: most mods never get finished. It's very rare that a mod gets finished, you guys are just spoiled because you are watching me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze views his experiment with YouTube Shorts as a financial failure, noting they did not provide a return on the time invested in creating them.
context_findings.quote: The problem is with shorts, you're never going to make the money back. No one really watches those shorts. The shots that I've made so far, investment wise, has not been a wise decision.

context_findings.summary: Kaze, a German living in Canada, expresses a strong personal dissatisfaction with his home country.
context_findings.quote: Germany is the worst country to live in in the entire world. Maybe not the very worst, but it's in my top 10 list for sure.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that an explicit 'hard mode' is unnecessary for Mario 64, as players can create their own difficulty by adopting a riskier playstyle, which he sees as a core strength of the original game's design.
context_findings.quote: If you want a hard mode, just play risky.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided the initial concept for the box-opening mechanic, suggesting a zipper. While Kaze ultimately rejected the idea as thematically unfitting, it sparked the design process.
biobak.quote: The first idea Biobak had was that it would be a zipper that would be attached to here, and then you would open the zipper. But on second thought, I don't really like it.

biobak.summary: Kaze jokingly suggests Biobak is an avid player of Wordle and similar puzzle games.
biobak.quote: I have a feeling if I made like a wordle clone and published it to the app store, Biobak would play it. He would find it somehow.

zeina.summary: Kaze's work schedule is influenced by his personal life with Zeina, as he had to end the stream to be present for guests they were hosting.
zeina.quote: Oh, yeah, we have Zeina's friends over today, so I have to be there.

key_stories.title: From Zipper to Pull-Tab: Designing an Entrance
key_stories.summary: Kaze refined the idea for opening a level's central cardboard box, moving from an unfitting 'zipper' concept to a more thematic 'pull-tab'. This involved brainstorming, 3D modeling, and complex animation work to create a more cohesive and unique player experience.
key_stories.challenge: The team needed a thematically appropriate way for players to open a large cardboard box that serves as the entrance to a 'hell' area. The initial idea from Biobak was a zipper.
key_stories.process: Kaze rejected the zipper concept as unfitting. He brainstormed alternatives like ripping tape or tearing out staples. He ultimately decided on a pull-tab, then spent considerable time modeling it in Blender, creating a custom vertex animation for the pulling action, and programming the associated gameplay logic.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze implemented a perforated pull-tab that Mario grabs and pulls. This solution is more thematically consistent with the game's crafty aesthetic and provides a unique gameplay interaction.
key_stories.key_quote: I don't want to make a Romhack exhibiting random technology. That's not what I'm interested in.

key_stories.title: The Phantom Bowser Bug
key_stories.summary: Kaze hunted down a bizarre, emulator-specific bug where Mario would drop Bowser. Through a methodical debugging process, he traced the problem to a flaw in the original SM64 code and fixed it, showcasing his technical expertise in modifying the core engine.
key_stories.challenge: A perplexing bug in Course 14 caused Mario to spontaneously let go of Bowser. The issue was inconsistent, appearing on the Project64 emulator but not on Nemu.
key_stories.process: Kaze used the Nemu emulator's debugger to trace the code execution. He set a breakpoint on Mario's action state variable and discovered that an unrelated function, `reset_intro_scene`, was being called and overwriting the state. He realized the original game code sometimes used `action_arg` and `action_state` interchangeably and corrected the logic.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully fixed the bug by correcting a function in the vanilla SM64 code that was improperly using two different state variables. The fix demonstrates his deep understanding of the engine and his ability to debug at a low level.
key_stories.key_quote: Something is overwriting the action arc only in this level without telling me. And only when you're holding Bowser. Doesn't make any sense.
